lines.content: Shade is a command-line task management application that helps users track different types of tasks with persistent storage.
1. Run `gradle build` in the project root
See the [User Guide](docs/README.md) for detailed usage instructions.
Run `gradle test` to run all tests
Run `gradle checkstyleMain` to run checkstyle on the main source set
If you run into any issues, please open a new issue on the github repository

Shade Chatbot is an interactive task management assistant designed to help you stay organized. It supports adding tasks, setting deadlines, scheduling events, and managing your task list efficiently. With its simple commands and intuitive interface, Shade Chatbot is your personal productivity companion.
> Words in angle brackets are the parameters to be supplied by the user.
> e.g. in `todo <task>`, `<task>` is a parameter which can be used as `todo Water the plants`.
> Items in square brackets are optional.
> e.g `<YYYY-MM-DD> [HH:mm]` can be used as `2025-03-03 09:00` or as `2025-03-03`.
The `help` command displays a list of all available commands and their descriptions.
The `todo` command lets you add a general task without a specific date or time.
The chatbot will confirm that the to-do task has been added:
Got it! I've added this task:
Now you have 3 tasks in the list.
The `deadline` command allows you to add a task with a specific due date (and optional time) to your task list.
> If no time is provided, it will default to 23:59.
The chatbot will confirm that the deadline task has been added:
Got it! I've added this task:
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
The `event` command allows you to schedule an event with a start and end date/time.
> If no time is provided, it will default to 23:59.
The chatbot will confirm that the event has been scheduled:
Got it! I've added this task:
[E][ ] Team meeting (from: Feb 22 2025, 2:00 PM to: Feb 22 2025, 4:00 PM)
Now you have 5 tasks in the list.
The `list` command displays all tasks currently in your task list.
3. [E][ ] Team meeting (from: Feb 22 2025, 2:00 PM to: Feb 22 2025, 4:00 PM)
The `find` command allows you to search for tasks containing specific keywords. The search is case-insensitive.
Tasks matching the keyword will be displayed:
The `mark` and `unmark` commands let you mark a task as done or undo that status.
The task number refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
The `delete` command removes a specific task from your list.
The task number refers to the index number shown in the displayed task list.
The chatbot will confirm the deletion:
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
Use the `quit` command to exit Shade Chatbot.
Task data are saved in the hard disk automatically after the program closes. There is no need to save manually.
Task data are saved automatically as a JSON file [JAR file location]/data/tasks.json. Advanced users are welcome to update data directly by editing that data file.

> If your changes to the data file makes its format invalid, Shade will discard all data and start with an empty data file at the next run. Hence, it is recommended to take a backup of the file before editing it.

> Furthermore, certain edits can cause Shade to behave in unexpected ways (e.g., if a value entered is outside of the acceptable range). Therefore, edit the data file only if you are confident that you can update it correctly.

* Represents an abstract base class for commands that can be executed with provided arguments.
* Subclasses must implement specific command behavior by overriding the execute method.
* The command trigger word or phrase.
* A brief description of what the command does.
* Constructs a Command with the specified trigger, description, and usage.
* @param trigger     The command trigger word or phrase.
* @param description A brief description of what the command does.
public Command(String trigger, String description, String usage) {
* Executes the defined logic for the command with the provided arguments.
* The behavior of this method should be implemented by specific command classes.
* @param arguments The arguments passed to the command for execution.
* @throws InvalidCommandSyntaxException If the command arguments are in an incorrect format.
public abstract void execute(String arguments) throws InvalidCommandSyntaxException;
* Returns the usage information for the command.
* @return A string containing the usage instructions and description of the command.

* @param ioHandler The IoHandler instance used to handle input and output operations.

* Executes the deadline command to create a new deadline task and add it to the associated TaskList.
* @param arguments The description of the task to be added and its deadline.
* @throws InvalidCommandSyntaxException If the task description or deadline is empty/invalid.
public void execute(String arguments) throws InvalidCommandSyntaxException {
throw new InvalidCommandSyntaxException("Uh oh, task should not be empty!");
// Split the arguments into task description and deadline
throw new InvalidCommandSyntaxException("Expected 2 arguments, only got " + parts.length + ".");
throw new InvalidCommandSyntaxException("Invalid date format! Use 'yyyy-MM-dd' or 'yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm'.");
assert deadline != null : "Deadline should not be null";
assert !parts[0].isEmpty() : "Task description should not be empty";
ioHandler.send("Got it. I've added this task:\n  "

* @return A string representation of all tasks in the list with indices and details.

* The search is case-sensitive and is based on the task descriptions.

* index and description. If no tasks are present, a default message is returned indicating
* @return A string representation of all tasks in the task list.
